question_text:
Find the union of each of the following pairs of sets:
(i) X = {1, 3, 5} and Y = {1, 2, 3}.
(ii) A = {a, e, i, o, u} and B = {a, b, c}.
(iii) A = {x : x is a natural number and a multiple of 3} and B = {x : x is a natural number less than 6}.
(iv) A = {x : x is a natural number and 1 < x ≤ 6} and B = {x : x is a natural number and 6 < x < 10}.
(v) A = {1, 2, 3} and B = ∅.
correct_answer:
(i) {1, 2, 3, 5}.
(ii) {a, b, c, e, i, o, u}.
(iii) {x ∈ ℕ : x < 6 or x is a multiple of 3} (explicitly, {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} ∪ {3, 6, 9, …}); note that 3 appears in both sets so it is not repeated.
(iv) {2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9}.
(v) {1, 2, 3}.
explanation:
For each pair, take all elements that appear in either set (without repetition). 
(i) X ∪ Y: X = {1, 3, 5} and Y = {1, 2, 3}; combine to get {1, 2, 3, 5}.
(ii) A ∪ B: A = {a, e, i, o, u} and B = {a, b, c}; the union is {a, b, c, e, i, o, u}.
(iii) Write A in set‐builder notation as all natural numbers divisible by 3 (i.e. {3, 6, 9, …}) and B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}. Their union is the set of all numbers that satisfy at least one of the conditions, which may be expressed as {x ∈ ℕ : (x < 6) or (x is a multiple of 3)}. (Listing elements explicitly up to a point: {1,2,3,4,5,6,9, …}).
(iv) A = {x ∈ ℕ : 1 < x ≤ 6} gives {2, 3, 4, 5, 6} and B = {x ∈ ℕ : 6 < x < 10} gives {7, 8, 9}. Their union is {2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9}.
(v) The union of any set with the empty set ∅ is the set itself, so {1, 2, 3} ∪ ∅ = {1, 2, 3}.

question_text: Let 𝒜 = {a, b} and ℬ = {a, b, c}. Determine whether 𝒜 ⊂ ℬ and find 𝒜 ∪ ℬ.
correct_answer: 𝒜 ⊂ ℬ is true because every element of {a, b} is in {a, b, c}. The union 𝒜 ∪ ℬ is {a, b, c}.
explanation: Since all elements of 𝒜 = {a, b} are contained in ℬ = {a, b, c}, we have 𝒜 ⊂ ℬ. The union operation takes all unique elements from both sets, so {a, b} ∪ {a, b, c} yields {a, b, c}.

question_text: If A and B are two sets such that A ⊆ B, what is A ∪ B?
explanation: When A is a subset of B, every element of A is already in B. Therefore, taking the union of A with B does not introduce any new elements; the result is simply B.

question_text:
Given A = {1, 2, 3, 4}, B = {3, 4, 5, 6}, C = {5, 6, 7, 8}, and D = {7, 8, 9, 10}, find:
(i) A ∪ B
(ii) A ∪ C
(iii) B ∪ C
(iv) B ∪ D
(v) A ∪ B ∪ C
(vi) A ∪ B ∪ D
(vii) B ∪ C ∪ D
explanation: Each union is found by combining the elements from the sets involved without duplication. For example, in (i), A has {1, 2, 3, 4} and B has {3, 4, 5, 6}. Their union is {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. The other parts follow similarly by taking all unique elements from the specified sets.

question_text:
Using the sets provided in Question 1, find the intersection of each pair:
(i) X = {1, 3, 5} and Y = {1, 2, 3}.
(ii) A = {a, e, i, o, u} and B = {a, b, c}.
(iii) A = {x : x is a natural number and a multiple of 3} and B = {x : x is a natural number less than 6}.
(iv) A = {x : x is a natural number and 1 < x ≤ 6} and B = {x : x is a natural number and 6 < x < 10}.
(v) A = {1, 2, 3} and B = ∅.
explanation:
The intersection of two sets contains only the elements common to both sets. 
(i) Both X and Y share 1 and 3, so the intersection is {1, 3}.
(ii) The only common element between {a, e, i, o, u} and {a, b, c} is a.
(iii) The only multiple of 3 that is less than 6 is 3.
(iv) There are no common elements between a set of numbers greater than 1 and up to 6, and a set of numbers strictly between 6 and 10.
(v) The intersection with the empty set is always empty.

Determine each intersection step by step:
(i) The common elements between A and B are 7, 9, and 11.
(ii) B and C share 11 and 13.
(iii) The only common element between A and C is 11, but 11 is not in D; hence, the triple intersection is empty.
(iv) A ∩ C gives {11}.
(v) B and D have no element in common.
(vi) First, compute B ∪ C = {7, 9, 11, 13, 15}; then A ∩ (B ∪ C) = {7, 9, 11}.
(vii) A and D are disjoint, so their intersection is ∅.
(viii) B ∪ D = {7, 9, 11, 13, 15, 17}; intersecting this with A gives {7, 9, 11}.
(ix) (A ∩ B) is {7, 9, 11} and B ∪ C contains all those elements, so the intersection remains {7, 9, 11}.
(x) A ∪ D = {3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 15, 17} and B ∪ C = {7, 9, 11, 13, 15}; their intersection is {7, 9, 11, 15}.

question_text:
Let A = {x : x is a natural number}, B = {x : x is an even natural number}, C = {x : x is an odd natural number}, and D = {x : x is a prime number}. Find:
(i) A ∩ B
(ii) A ∩ C
(iii) A ∩ D
(iv) B ∩ C
(v) B ∩ D
(vi) C ∩ D
correct_answer:
(i) A ∩ B is the set of even natural numbers (i.e. B).
(ii) A ∩ C is the set of odd natural numbers (i.e. C).
(iii) A ∩ D is the set of prime numbers.
(iv) B ∩ C = ∅, since no number can be both even and odd.
(v) B ∩ D = {2}, as 2 is the only even prime.
(vi) C ∩ D = {all odd prime numbers} (i.e. primes excluding 2).
explanation: Since A represents all natural numbers, intersecting with B (even numbers) or C (odd numbers) returns B or C respectively. The set D is the set of prime numbers. Only 2 is both even and prime, hence B ∩ D = {2}. No number can simultaneously be even and odd, which means B ∩ C is empty. The intersection of C and D gives the set of primes that are odd (3, 5, 7, …).

question_text:
Determine which of the following pairs of sets are disjoint:
(i) {1, 2, 3, 4} and {x : x is a natural number and 4 ≤ x ≤ 6}.
(ii) {a, e, i, o, u} and {c, d, e, f}.
(iii) {x : x is an even integer} and {x : x is an odd integer}.
correct_answer:
(i) Not disjoint (they share 4).
(ii) Not disjoint (they share e).
(iii) Disjoint.
explanation:
Two sets are disjoint if they have no elements in common. 
(i) The set {1, 2, 3, 4} and the set {4, 5, 6} share the element 4 and are therefore not disjoint.
(ii) The vowels set {a, e, i, o, u} and the set {c, d, e, f} share the element e, so they are not disjoint.
(iii) By definition, even integers and odd integers have no member in common, making them disjoint.

question_text:
Given A = {3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21}, B = {4, 8, 12, 16, 20}, C = {2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16}, and D = {5, 10, 15, 20}, find the following set differences:
(i) A – B
(ii) A – C
(iii) A – D
(iv) B – A
(v) C – A
(vi) D – A
(vii) B – C
(viii) B – D
(ix) C – B
(x) D – B
(xi) C – D
(xii) D – C
explanation: For each difference A – B, we list all elements in A that are not in B. For example, in (i), A = {3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21} and B = {4, 8, 12, 16, 20}. The common element is 12, so removing 12 from A gives {3, 6, 9, 15, 18, 21}. The remaining parts are computed with the same idea by identifying common elements and removing them from the first set.

question_text:
Let X = {a, b, c, d} and Y = {f, b, d, g}. Find:
(i) X – Y
(ii) Y – X
(iii) X ∩ Y
correct_answer:
(i) X – Y = {a, c}.
(ii) Y – X = {f, g}.
(iii) X ∩ Y = {b, d}.
explanation: Subtracting Y from X means removing the elements of Y from X. Since b and d are common to both, X – Y = {a, c}. Similarly, Y – X removes b and d from Y, resulting in {f, g}. The intersection takes the common elements of both sets, which are {b, d}.

question_text: If ℝ is the set of real numbers and ℚ is the set of rational numbers, what is ℝ – ℚ?
correct_answer: ℝ – ℚ is the set of irrational numbers.
explanation: The set of real numbers consists of both rational and irrational numbers. Removing all rational numbers ℚ from ℝ leaves only those numbers that cannot be expressed as the ratio of two integers, which are defined as the irrational numbers.

question_text:
For each of the following statements, state whether it is true or false and justify your answer:
(i) {2, 3, 4, 5} and {3, 6} are disjoint sets.
(ii) {a, e, i, o, u} and {a, b, c, d} are disjoint sets.
(iii) {2, 6, 10, 14} and {3, 7, 11, 15} are disjoint sets.
(iv) {2, 6, 10} and {3, 7, 11} are disjoint sets.
explanation: Two sets are disjoint if they have no elements in common. In (i), the sets share the element 3, and in (ii) they share the element a, so those are false. In (iii) and (iv), there are no common elements between the two sets, making the statements true.
